Knowledge Point: The first element in the clause can be a temporal noun phrase (\ref{ex:10:1}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Apazan} albaya ahay tolo a ləhe. | \gll \textbf{apazaŋ} albaja=ahaj tɔ-lɔ a lɪhɛ | \gls yesterday youth=Pl 3P+PFV-go at bush | \glt ‘Yesterday the youths went to the bush.’

Knowledge Point: The subject is expressed by the subject pronominal on the verb (\sectref{sec:7.3.1}). A coreferential noun phrase can be present for discourse functions (\ref{ex:10:2} and \ref{ex:10:3}). The coreferential noun phrase precedes the verb.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Hawa} ahəmay. | \gll \textbf{Hawa} à-həm-aj | \gls Hawa 3S+PFV-run-CL | \glt ‘Hawa ran.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ne ahan} nozom na. | \gll \textbf{nɛ}\textbf{=ahaŋ} n\'{ɔ}-zɔm na | \gls oneS=3S.POSS 3S+PFV-eat 3S.DO | \glt ‘I myself ate it.’

Knowledge Point: The examples below are clauses consisting of just a verb complex. They all have information on the subject (from subject inflections, \ref{ex:10:4}, \ref{ex:10:6}, \ref{ex:10:7}, \ref{ex:10:8}) or the form of the imperative (\ref{ex:10:5} and \ref{ex:10:9}). Some have information on the direct object (\ref{ex:10:6}--\ref{ex:10:9}), indirect object (\ref{ex:10:8} and \ref{ex:10:9}), direction of the action (\ref{ex:10:5}, \ref{ex:10:7}, \ref{ex:10:9}), and discourse information \REF{ex:10:5}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nəhəmay. | \gll n\`{ə}-həm-aj | \gls 1S+PFV-run-\CL | \glt ‘I ran.’
Content 2: Not found
Content 4: \gsrc Nəvəlan na. | \gll n\`{ə}-vəl=aŋ na | \gls oneS+PFV-give=3S.IO 3S.DO | \glt ‘I gave it to him.’
Content 5: \gsrc Dəraka alay! | \gll dər=aka=alaj | \gls move=on=away | \glt ‘Move further over!’
Content 6: \gsrc Zaw na ala! | \gll z=aw na=ala | \gls carry[twoS.IMP]=oneS.IO 3S.DO=to | \glt ‘Bring it to me!’
Content 8: \gsrc Zaw na ala! | \gll z=aw na=ala | \gls carry[twoS.IMP]=oneS.IO 3S.DO=to | \glt ‘Bring it to me!’
Content 9: \gsrc Nəvəlan na. | \gll n\`{ə}-vəl=aŋ na | \gls oneS+PFV-give=3S.IO 3S.DO | \glt ‘I gave it to him.’
Content 10: \gsrc Zaw na ala! | \gll z=aw na=ala | \gls carry[twoS.IMP]=oneS.IO 3S.DO=to | \glt ‘Bring it to me!’

Knowledge Point: Predicate nominal (\ref{ex:10:10}--\ref{ex:10:12}), predicate adjective \REF{ex:10:13}, and predicate possessive (\ref{ex:10:14} and \ref{ex:10:15}) clauses lack any verb and consist of a juxtaposition of two noun phrases, in an order shown in \figref{fig:17}.
Content 1: \gsrc  [Mana ] [zar mehere]. | \gll [Mana] [zar mɛ-hɛr-ɛ] | \gls Mana man NOM-build-CL | \glt ‘Mana [is] a builder.’ (lit. Mana, building-man)
Content 2: \gsrc [Zar nehe] [baba əwla]. | \gll [zar nɛhɛ] [baba=uwla] | \gls man DEM father=oneS.POSS | \glt ‘The man [is] my father.’
Content 4: \gsrc  [Babəza ahay nəndəye] [\textbf{anga} bahay]. | \gll [babəza=ahaj nɪndijɛ] [\textbf{aŋga} bahaj] | \gls children=Pl DEM POSS chief | \glt ‘The children here belong to the chief.’ / ‘The children here[are] belonging to the chief.’
Content 5: \gsrc [Dəray ga] [\textbf{anga} ləme]. | \gll [dəraj ga] [\textbf{aŋga} lɪmɛ] | \gls head ADJ POSS 1PEX | \glt ‘The head belonged to us.’/ ‘The head [was] belonging to us.’

Knowledge Point: Predicate nominal clauses typically express the notions of proper inclusion (i.e., the clause indicates that the subject is a member of the particular class of items indicated by the predicate, \ref{ex:10:10}) or equation (i.e., the clause indicates that the subject is identical to the predicate, \ref{ex:10:11} and \ref{ex:10:12}). In the following examples, each noun phrase is delimited by square brackets.
Content 1: \gsrc  [Mana ] [zar mehere]. | \gll [Mana] [zar mɛ-hɛr-ɛ] | \gls Mana man NOM-build-CL | \glt ‘Mana [is] a builder.’ (lit. Mana, building-man)
Content 2: \gsrc [Sləmay əwla] [Abangay]. | \gll [ɬəmaj=uwla] [Abaŋgaj] | \gls name=oneS.POSS Abangay | \glt ‘My name [is] Abangay.’
Content 3: \gsrc [Zar nehe] [baba əwla]. | \gll [zar nɛhɛ] [baba=uwla] | \gls man DEM father=oneS.POSS | \glt ‘The man [is] my father.’

Knowledge Point: (\sectref{sec:5.3}) as the predicate noun phrase. These clauses express an attribute of the subject \REF{ex:10:13}.
Content 1: \gsrc [Ndahan] [malan ga]. | \gll [ndahaŋ] [malaŋ ga] | \gls 3S largeness ADJ | \glt ‘He/she [is] big.’

Knowledge Point: For all three of these clause types, the subject may be marked as presupposed (see \sectref{sec:11.2}). For a predicate nominal construction, fronting and marking the predicate with na expresses equation in (\ref{ex:10:16}--\ref{ex:10:18}).
Content 1: \gsrc [Zar mehere na], [Mana]. | \gll [zar mɛ-hɛr-ɛ] na [Mana] | \gls man NOM-build-CL PSP Mana | \glt ‘The builder [is] Mana.’
Content 2: \gsrc [Malan ga na], [ndahan]. | \gll [malaŋ ga] na [ndahaŋ] | \gls largeness ADJ PSP 3S | \glt ‘The biggest one [is] him.’ (lit. big, him)

Knowledge Point: The all-purpose negative is the particle bay, which follows the verb phrase and occurs (\ref{ex:10:19}--\ref{ex:10:21}) before any interrogative word (see \sectref{sec:10.3}). In the examples in this section, the negative is bolded and the negation construction is in square brackets.
Content 1: \gsrc [Alala \textbf{bay}]. | \gll [à-l=ala \textbf{baj}] | \gls 3S+PFV-go=to NEG | \glt ‘He/she didn’t come.’
Content 2: \gsrc [Táazləgalay avəlo \textbf{bay}]. | \gll [táá-ɮəg=alaj avʊlɔ \textbf{baj}] | \gls 3P+POT-throw=away above NEG | \glt ‘They should not throw it too high.’

Knowledge Point: In (\ref{ex:10:22}--\ref{ex:10:24}) the negative is clause-final and may have sematic scope over the entire proposition (c.f. constituent negation, \sectref{sec:10.2.3}). See especially \REF{ex:10:23} where it is clear that the entire proposition is being negated, and not just the information within the constituent closest to the negative. The meaning is ‘don’t insult a small person.’ If the information in only one constituent was being negated, the meaning would have been ‘insult a person who is not small.’
Content 1: \gsrc [Tagaw ele lala \textbf{bay}]. | \gll [ta-g=aw ɛlɛ lala \textbf{baj}] | \gls 3P-do=oneS.IO thing good NEG | \glt ‘They do bad things to me.’ / ‘They don’t do good things to me.’
Content 2: \gsrc [Anday dəren \textbf{bay}]. | \gll [à-ndaj dɪrɛŋ \textbf{baj}] | \gls 3S+PFV-PRG far NEG | \glt ‘He/she was not far.’
Content 3: \gsrc [Kárasay məze cəɗew ga \textbf{bay}]. | \gll [ká-ras-aj mɪʒɛ tʃɪɗɛw ga \textbf{baj}] | \gls twoS+IFV-minimise-CL person smallness ADJ NEG | \glt ‘Don’t insult one of the little people.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:10:25}, bay is not clause final but is the final element in a noun phrase within the clause. In this case, the information expressed within the noun phrase itself is negated; ele lala \textbf{bay} ‘a bad thing.’
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: When relative clauses are negated, the negative may have semantic scope over the entire relative clause (\ref{ex:10:26}, \ref{ex:10:27}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: For clausal negation, there is no change in word order and no change in clause constituents apart from the addition of the clause final negative particle. A negative clause asserts that some event or state does not hold. Various types of clausal negation in Moloko are illustrated in (\ref{ex:10:28}--\ref{ex:10:43}). Each pair of examples represents a positive and a negative assertion for comparison.
Content 1: \gsrc Ahəmay. | \gll a-həm-aj | \gls 3S-run-CL | \glt ‘He/she runs.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndahan gədan ga \textbf{bay.} | \gll ndahaŋ gədaŋ ga \textbf{baj} | \gls 3S strength ADJ NEG | \glt ‘He/she is not strong.’

Knowledge Point: The negation of an intransitive clause is illustrated in \REF{ex:10:28} and \REF{ex:10:29}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ahəmay. | \gll a-həm-aj | \gls 3S-run-CL | \glt ‘He/she runs.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ahəmay \textbf{bay.} | \gll a-həm-aj \textbf{baj} | \gls 3S-run-CL NEG | \glt ‘He/she doesn’t run.’

Knowledge Point: THe negation of a transitive clause is shown in (\ref{ex:10:30}--\ref{ex:10:35}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Asaw sese \textbf{bay.} | \gll a-s=aw ʃɛʃɛ \textbf{baj} | \gls 3S-please=oneS.IO meat NEG | \glt ‘I do not want meat.’

Knowledge Point: The negation of existentials is shown in (\ref{ex:10:36}--\ref{ex:10:39}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Dala anaw aka \textbf{bay.} | \gll dala an=aw aka \textbf{baj} | \gls money DAT=oneS EXT+on NEG | \glt ‘I have no money.’

Knowledge Point: The negation of a predicate adjective is illustrated in (\ref{ex:10:40}--\ref{ex:10:43}).
Content 1: \gsrc Ndahan zləle ga. | \gll ndahaŋ ɮɪlɛ ga | \gls 3S richness ADJ | \glt ‘He/she is rich.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndahan gədan ga \textbf{bay.} | \gll ndahaŋ gədaŋ ga \textbf{baj} | \gls 3S strength ADJ NEG | \glt ‘He/she is not strong.’

Knowledge Point: Most frequently, it seems that the element closest to the negative that is under the scope of negation, even though a clause-final negative marker can have scope over the whole verb phrase or even over the entire clause. To negate only one constituent in a clause, the clause is sometimes rearranged so that the constituent that is negated is placed in the clause-final position adjacent to the negation particle. Examples (\ref{ex:10:44}--\ref{ex:10:46}) show a question \REF{ex:10:44} with two responses (\ref{ex:10:45}--\ref{ex:10:46}) where each of the two ambiguous elements is negated. The subject (Mana) is part of the presupposition (marked off by na in the question, see \sectref{sec:11.2}). In \REF{ex:10:45} the oblique is negated and in \REF{ex:10:46} the entire predicate. The clauses were not restructured since the elements in question were already clause-final. In the following examples, the element that is negated is delimited by square brackets and the negative is bolded.
Content 1: \gsrc Mana na, olo [a kosoko ava] ɗaw? | \gll Mana na ɔ-lɔ [a kɔsɔkʷɔ ava] ɗaw | \gls Mana PSP 3S-go at market in {Q | \glt ‘As for Mana, is he going to the market?’
Content 2: \gsrc Ehe, olo [a kosoko ava] \textbf{bay}; enjé a mogom. | \gll ɛhɛ, [ɔ-lɔ a kɔsɔkʷɔ ava] \textbf{baj} ɛ-nʒ-ɛ a mɔgʷɔm | \gls no 3S-go at market in NEG 3S-stay-CL at home | \glt ‘No, he isn’t going to the market; rather he is staying at home (or going to the chief’s house).’
Content 3: \gsrc Mana na, olo [a kosoko ava] ɗaw? | \gll Mana na ɔ-lɔ [a kɔsɔkʷɔ ava] ɗaw | \gls Mana PSP 3S-go at market in {Q | \glt ‘As for Mana, is he going to the market?’
Content 5: \gsrc Ehe, olo [a kosoko ava] \textbf{bay}; enjé a mogom. | \gll ɛhɛ, [ɔ-lɔ a kɔsɔkʷɔ ava] \textbf{baj} ɛ-nʒ-ɛ a mɔgʷɔm | \gls no 3S-go at market in NEG 3S-stay-CL at home | \glt ‘No, he isn’t going to the market; rather he is staying at home (or going to the chief’s house).’
Content 7: \gsrc Ehe, olo [a kosoko ava] \textbf{bay}; enjé a mogom. | \gll ɛhɛ, [ɔ-lɔ a kɔsɔkʷɔ ava] \textbf{baj} ɛ-nʒ-ɛ a mɔgʷɔm | \gls no 3S-go at market in NEG 3S-stay-CL at home | \glt ‘No, he isn’t going to the market; rather he is staying at home (or going to the chief’s house).’

Knowledge Point: Examples (\ref{ex:10:47}--\ref{ex:10:50}) show some restructuring when different constituents are negated. Example \REF{ex:10:47} illustrates a question and \REF{ex:10:48} to \REF{ex:10:50} illustrate three possible answers, each negating a different constituent. Normal SVO structure is maintained for all answers. The responses each use two clauses. The first clause expresses the negation of the element in final position, and the second restates the clause giving the corrected information. In each case the first clause is restructured so as to move the element to be negated to the clause-final position. The response in \REF{ex:10:48} indicates that the hearer accepts 'that Mana gave the guitar to someone,' but it was not his father. In this clause, kəndew ‘guitar’ is realised as the \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s} \DO pronominal. The response in \REF{ex:10:49} indicates 'that Mana gave something to his father,' but not a guitar. In this case, the adpositional phrase ana baba ahan ‘to his father’ is replaced by the indirect object pronominal so that the negated element kəndew ‘guitar’ can be placed next to the negative.
Content 1: \gsrc Mana avəlan kəndew ana baba ahan ɗaw? | \gll Mana à-vəl=aŋ kɪndɛw ana baba=ahaŋ ɗaw | \gls Mana 3S+PFV-give=3S.IO guitar DAT father=3S.POSS {Q | \glt ‘Did Mana give the guitar to his father?’
Content 2: \gsrc Ehe, aməvəlan kəndew ana baba ahan na, [Mana] bay; | \gll ɛhɛ amə-vəl=aŋ kɪndɛw ana baba=ahaŋ na [Mana] baj | \gls no DEP-give=3S.IO guitar DAT father=3S.POSS PSP Mana NEG | \glt ‘No, Mana didn’t give the guitar to his father. (lit. the one that gave guitar to his father, not Mana)’
Content 3: \gsrc Mana avəlan kəndew ana baba ahan ɗaw? | \gll Mana à-vəl=aŋ kɪndɛw ana baba=ahaŋ ɗaw | \gls Mana 3S+PFV-give=3S.IO guitar DAT father=3S.POSS {Q | \glt ‘Did Mana give the guitar to his father?’
Content 5: \gsrc Ehe, aməvəlan kəndew ana baba ahan na, [Mana] bay; | \gll ɛhɛ amə-vəl=aŋ kɪndɛw ana baba=ahaŋ na [Mana] baj | \gls no DEP-give=3S.IO guitar DAT father=3S.POSS PSP Mana NEG | \glt ‘No, Mana didn’t give the guitar to his father. (lit. the one that gave guitar to his father, not Mana)’
Content 7: \gsrc Ehe, avəlan [kəndew] \textbf{bay}, avəlan cecewk. | \gll ɛhɛ à-vəl=aŋ [kɪndɛw] \textbf{baj} à-vəl=aŋ tʃɛtʃœkʷ | \gls no 3S+PFV-give=3S.IO guitar NEG 3S+PFV-give=3S.IO flute | \glt ‘No, he didn’t give a guitar to his father, he gave him a flute.’

Knowledge Point: The fourth possible reply to the question in \REF{ex:10:47} negates the subject. Moloko clause structure does not allow the subject to occupy the clause-final position; to specifically negate the subject of a clause \REF{ex:10:52}, a predicate nominal clause structure is used. The predicate is recast as a relative clause (see \sectref{sec:5.4.3}) with the presupposed information that someone gave a guitar to his father marked with na. The nominal is the negated subject Mana bay ‘not Mana.’
Content 1: \gsrc Mana avəlan kəndew ana baba ahan ɗaw? | \gll Mana à-vəl=aŋ kɪndɛw ana baba=ahaŋ ɗaw | \gls Mana 3S+PFV-give=3S.IO guitar DAT father=3S.POSS {Q | \glt ‘Did Mana give the guitar to his father?’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Examples (\ref{ex:10:51}--\ref{ex:10:52}) show a similar restructuring of a verbal clause into a predicate nominal in order to negate the subject of a clause. A question with a verbal clause structure is shown in \REF{ex:10:51}. In order to negate the subject, the clause is restructured to put all of the known information in a predicate that is a relative clause delimited by na, and the negated subject becomes the final nominal \REF{ex:10:52}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The first clause structure that is employed is the verbal clause structure (SVO), but with substitution of a question word. The verbal clause structure is rearranged in the same manner as for constituent negation (see \sectref{sec:10.2.3}) in order to position the questioned element in the clause-final position so that it is replaced by the interrogative pronoun. Information questions in verbal clauses are paired with a response in (\ref{ex:10:53}--\ref{ex:10:65}) so that the structure of the interrogative clause can be compared with that of the declarative. Examples in this section are given in pairs. The first example in the pair shows the interrogative construction. The second example is the clause with the information filled in for comparison.
Content 1: \gsrc Zar amənjar [\textbf{way}]? | \gll zar à-mənzar [\textbf{waj}] | \gls man 3S+PFV-see who | \glt ‘Who did the man see?’
Content 2: \gsrc Nolo [a kosoko ava]. | \gll n\'{ɔ}-lɔ [\textbf{a} kɔsɔkʷɔ \textbf{ava}] | \gls oneS+PFV-go at market in | \glt ‘I went to market.’

Knowledge Point: \largerpage The direct object is questioned in \REF{ex:10:53}. The presupposed information is that the man saw someone. Note that there are no other elements that follow the direct object in the verb phrase. The interrogative pronoun fills the direct object slot (identified by square brackets).
Content 1: \gsrc Zar amənjar [\textbf{way}]? | \gll zar à-mənzar [\textbf{waj}] | \gls man 3S+PFV-see who | \glt ‘Who did the man see?’

Knowledge Point: A noun modifier is questioned in \REF{ex:10:55}. The presupposed information is that the woman made some kind of sauce, and the question seeks to find out what kind of sauce. The interrogative pronoun weley ‘which’ is within the noun phrase delimited by square brackets in the example. Even though the interrogative pronoun is inside a noun phrase, that noun phrase is clause-final so the interrogative pronoun is the final word in the clause.
Content 1: \gsrc Hor ede [elele \textbf{weley}]? | \gll hʷɔr ɛ-dɛ [ɛlɛlɛ \textbf{wɛlɛj}] | \gls woman 3S-prepare sauce which | \glt ‘The woman is making which kind of sauce?’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:10:57} questions the direct object of a subordinate clause, in this case a purpose adverbial clause (delimited by square brackets). The presupposed information is that the listener has come to do something. The interrogative pronoun almay ‘what’ is clause-final since the adverbial clause has no other elements following the direct object. Two possible responses are shown in \REF{ex:10:58}--\REF{ex:10:59}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kəlala [aməgəye \textbf{almay}]? | \gll k\`{ə}-l=ala [amɪ-g-ijɛ \textbf{almaj}] | \gls twoS+PFV-go=to DEP-do-CL what | \glt ‘What have you come to do?’ (lit. you have come to do what?)
Content 2: \gsrc Nəlala [aməgəye slərele]. | \gll n\`{ə}-l=ala [amɪ-g-ijɛ ɬɪrɛlɛ] | \gls oneS+PFV-go=to DEP-do-CL work | \glt ‘I came to do work.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nəlala [aməjənok]. | \gll n\`{ə}-l=ala [amə-dzən-ɔkʷ] | \gls oneS+PFV-go=to DEP-help-twoS | \glt ‘I came to help you.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:10:60}, the indirect object is questioned. The presupposed information is that Mala gave a book to someone. The interrogative pronoun way ‘who,’ is located within a prepositional phrase identified by square brackets. That prepositional phrase is clause-final, so that again the interrogative pronoun is the final element in the clause.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:10:62} and \REF{ex:10:64}, an oblique is questioned. The presupposed information is that the woman plans to go to market sometime. The interrogative pronoun is the temporal element in the clause in \REF{ex:10:62}. While temporal noun phrases can occur clause-initially, the interrogative pronoun is again found in the clause-final position.
Content 1: \gsrc Hor olo a kosoko ava [\textbf{epeley}]? | \gll hʷɔr ɔ-lɔ a kɔsɔkʷɔ ava [\textbf{ɛpɛlɛj}] | \gls woman 3S-go at market in when | \glt ‘When is the woman going to market?’
Content 2: \gsrc Kolo [\textbf{amtamay}]? | \gll k\'{ɔ}-lɔ [\textbf{amtamaj}] | \gls twoS+PFV-go where | \glt ‘Where did you go?’
Content 3: \gsrc Hor olo a kosoko ava [\textbf{epeley}]? | \gll hʷɔr ɔ-lɔ a kɔsɔkʷɔ ava [\textbf{ɛpɛlɛj}] | \gls woman 3S-go at market in when | \glt ‘When is the woman going to market?’

Knowledge Point: The elements within non-core adpositional phrases are questioned using the generic location question word amtamay ‘where’ \REF{ex:10:64}. This generic location question word does not need to be located inside an adpositional phrase, eliminating the possibility that the locational postposition would follow the interrogative pronoun in the clause allowing the interrogative pronoun to be clause-final. The presupposed information is that the hearer is going somewhere.
Content 1: \gsrc Kolo [\textbf{amtamay}]? | \gll k\'{ɔ}-lɔ [\textbf{amtamaj}] | \gls twoS+PFV-go where | \glt ‘Where did you go?’

Knowledge Point: The second clause structure that is employed for interrogative constructions is the predicate nominal. The predicate nominal structure is employed for questioning an element of a predicate nominal clause. (\ref{ex:10:66}–\ref{ex:10:71}) are example pairs where the first of each pair is a question and the second is a possible response. In \REF{ex:10:66} an aspect of the nominal is questioned with the interrogative pronoun in a prepositional phrase. The prepositional phrase is delimited by square brackets.
Content 1: \gsrc Mogom nehe [anga \textbf{way}]? | \gll mɔgʷɔm nɛhɛ [aŋga \textbf{waj}] | \gls house DEM POSS who | \glt ‘This house here belongs to whom?’
Content 2: \gsrc Bahay a slala əwla na [Ajəva]. | \gll bahaj a ɬala=uwla na [Adzəva] | \gls chief GEN village=oneS.POSS PSP Adziva | \glt ‘The chief of my village is Adziva.’
Content 3: \gsrc Mogom nehe [anga \textbf{way}]? | \gll mɔgʷɔm nɛhɛ [aŋga \textbf{waj}] | \gls house DEM POSS who | \glt ‘This house here belongs to whom?’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:10:68} and \REF{ex:10:70}, the interrogative word itself is the predicate.
Content 1: \gsrc Mogom ango [\textbf{amtamay}]? | \gll mɔgʷɔm=aŋgʷɔ [\textbf{amtamaj}] | \gls home=twoS.POSS where | \glt ‘Where is your home?’
Content 2: \gsrc Bahay a slala aləkwəye na [\textbf{way}]? | \gll bahaj a ɬala=alʊkʷøjɛ na [\textbf{waj}] | \gls chief GEN village=twoP.POSS PSP who | \glt ‘The chief of your village is who?’

Knowledge Point: The predicate nominal clause is also used for questioning the subject in what would otherwise be a normal verbal clause (paralleling the case for the negative, see \sectref{sec:10.2.3}). The subject of what would be a verbal clause in a declarative speech act cannot be questioned using the SVO verbal clause construction in Moloko, because the clause can never be simply rearranged so that the subject is clause-final. For example, it is impossible to question the subject in \REF{ex:10:72} using the SVO verbal clause construction.\footnote{Unless the emphatic question construction is used \sectref{sec:10.3.5}.}
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: To question the subject (\ref{ex:10:73}–\ref{ex:10:74}), the verbal clause must be reformed into a predicate nominal interrogative construction. The clause is reformed into a noun phrase with a relative clause so that the interrogative pronoun questioning the subject can be in clause-final position.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \REF{ex:10:75} and \REF{ex:10:77} show two other predicate nominal clauses that question what would be the subject of an otherwise verbal clause. \REF{ex:10:76} and \REF{ex:10:78} are possible responses to these questions.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Aməzəɗe dəray na \textbf{way}? | \gll amɪ-ʒɪɗ-ɛ dəraj na \textbf{waj} | \gls DEP-take-CL head PSP who | \glt ‘Who will win?’ (lit. the one that takes the head [is] who?)
Content 4: \gsrc Mana azaɗ dəray. | \gll Mana a-zaɗ dəraj | \gls Mana 3S-take head | \glt ‘Mana won.’ (lit. Mana took head)

Knowledge Point: The third structure for content information questions uses a right-shifted na{}-marked element (see \sectref{sec:11.3}). This structure is employed in cases where it is impossible for a questioned verb phrase element to be clause-final. In \REF{ex:10:79}, the direct object is questioned. In this case the direct object cannot be clause-final since it is necessary to include the information ana məlama ahan ‘to his brother,’ and the prepositional phrase must follow the direct object in the verb phrase (\chapref{chap:8}). Thus in the interrogative structure, the interrogative pronoun replaces the direct object and the rest of the clause is put into a post-posed na{}-marked phrase (underlined in this example). A possible response is shown in \REF{ex:10:80}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mala avəlan \textbf{almay} ana məlama ahan na? | \gll Mala a-vəl=aŋ \textbf{almaj} \ulp{ana}{~} \ulp{məlama}{~}\ulp{=ahaŋ}{~~~~} \ule{na} | \gls Mala 3S-give=3S.IO what DAT sibling=3S.POSS PSP | \glt ‘Mala gave what to his brother?’
Content 2: \gsrc Mala avəlan dala ana məlama ahan. | \gll Mala a-vəl=aŋ dala ana məlama=ahaŋ | \gls Mala 3S-give=3S.IO money DAT sibling=3S.POSS | \glt ‘Mala gave money to his brother.’

Knowledge Point: Yes/no questions are interrogative clauses which can be answered by a simple ‘yes’ or ‘no’ – they are not asking for content in the reply. Moloko uses the interrogative marker ɗaw at the end of what is otherwise a declarative clause to create yes/no interrogatives. Pure yes-no questions can be answered with either yes or no, but in Moloko there is often a degree of expectation to the question.\footnote{Expectation is a central element in understanding Moloko grammar (see \sectref{sec:7.4.3}), as is what constitutes shared information with the hearer (see \chapref{chap:11}). Questions are constructed in Moloko with that knowledge and expectation in mind, even when seeking new information. Tag questions are discussed in \sectref{sec:10.3.3}.} When a speaker asks a yes/no question (\ref{ex:10:81}–\ref{ex:10:83}), they are usually expecting an affirmative reply.
Content 1: \gsrc Zar na ndahan baba a Mala \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll zar na ndahaŋ baba a Mala \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls man PSP 3S father GEN Mala {Q | \glt ‘That man, is he Mala’s father?’
Content 2: \gsrc Zar ango ndahan aba \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll zar=aŋgʷɔ ndahaŋ aba \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls man=twoS.POSS 3S EXT {Q | \glt ‘Is your husband well?’ (part of a greeting; lit. your husband, does he exist?)

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:10:82}, the speaker expects that Mana is on his way; he is asking for confirmation (but a negative response is always possible). Likewise in \REF{ex:10:83}, he expects that the referent zar ango ‘your husband’ is well.
Content 1: \gsrc Mana na álala \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll Mana na á-l=ala \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls Mana PSP 3S+IPV-go=to {Q | \glt 'Mana, is he coming?'
Content 2: \gsrc Zar ango ndahan aba \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll zar=aŋgʷɔ ndahaŋ aba \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls man=twoS.POSS 3S EXT {Q | \glt ‘Is your husband well?’ (part of a greeting; lit. your husband, does he exist?)

Knowledge Point: There is often an even stronger affirmative expectation when the question is negated. Compare the positive and negative pairs of questions (\ref{ex:10:84}–\ref{ex:10:89}). Some of the negated questions can be used rhetorically (see \sectref{sec:10.3.4}), since the speaker already knows that the answer is yes. In the examples, the interrogative markers and the negative particles are bolded.
Content 1: \gsrc Baba ango, ndahan ava a mogom \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll baba=aŋgʷɔ ndahaŋ ava a mɔgʷɔm \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls father=twoS.POSS 3S EXT+in at home {Q | \glt ‘Is your father in?’
Content 2: \gsrc Məlama ango álala \textbf{bay} \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll məlama=aŋgʷɔ á-l=ala \textbf{baj} \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls sibling=twoS.POSS 3S+IFV-go=to NEG {Q | \glt ‘Is your brother not coming?’

Knowledge Point: As is the case for the negation construction (see \sectref{sec:10.2.3}), it could be that the entire proposition in the clause is being questioned. However, it is often the case that only the final constituent is being questioned. Often the clause is restructured when a constituent of the clause is questioned so that the constituent is in final position. In \REF{ex:10:90} the direct object is fronted and marked as presupposed (it is the topic of discussion) so that the other elements in the clause are questioned (see \sectref{sec:10.3.2}). See also \REF{ex:10:82} where the subject is marked as presupposed and it is whether or not he is coming that is being questioned.
Content 1: \gsrc Awak ango na, káaslay na \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll awak=aŋgʷɔ na káá-ɬ-aj na \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls goat=twoS.POSS PSP twoS+POT-slay-CL 3S.DO {Q | \glt ‘Your goat, are you going to slaughter it?’
Content 2: \gsrc Mana na álala \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll Mana na á-l=ala \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls Mana PSP 3S+IPV-go=to {Q | \glt 'Mana, is he coming?'

Knowledge Point: Other question tags are evaluative. Example \REF{ex:10:94} is a question tag asked in a context where the speaker is examining something physically (perhaps at the market as he is considering to buy it) or analysing and evaluating an event.
Content 1: \gsrc [Səlom ga] \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll [sʊlɔm ga] \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls goodness ADJ {Q | \glt ‘[Is that] good?’

Knowledge Point: In a rhetorical question, the speaker is not pragmatically asking for information. Rather, the questions can be evaluative, may carry an element of reproach, or may be a mild command. The context gives the rhetorical force. Some rhetorical questions have a special emphatic structure (see \sectref{sec:10.3.5}) but many have the normal interrogative structure for a content question (\ref{ex:10:95}–\ref{ex:10:96}, see \sectref{sec:10.3.1}). For example, the speaker is not seeking an explanation when he asks kamay ‘why’ in \REF{ex:10:95}. More probably he is making a strong statement, ‘the people had no reason to do this bad thing to me.’ Likewise in \REF{ex:10:96}, the speaker is saying that the listener will listen to no one.
Content 1: \gsrc Məze ahay tagaw ele lala bay \textbf{kamay}? | \gll mɪʒɛ=ahaj ta-g=aw ɛlɛ lala baj \textbf{kamaj} | \gls person=Pl 3P-do=oneS.IO thing good NEG why | \glt ‘The people had no reason to do this bad thing to me.’ (lit. the people did the bad thing to me why?)
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gsrc Məze ahay tagaw ele lala bay \textbf{kamay}? | \gll mɪʒɛ=ahaj ta-g=aw ɛlɛ lala baj \textbf{kamaj} | \gls person=Pl 3P-do=oneS.IO thing good NEG why | \glt ‘The people had no reason to do this bad thing to me.’ (lit. the people did the bad thing to me why?)

Knowledge Point: Other rhetorical questions have the same structure as a tag question (\ref{ex:10:97}–\ref{ex:10:98}, see \sectref{sec:10.3.3}). However either there is no expected answer or the expected answer is the opposite of that for a normal yes/no tag question. For example, during the telling of the text from which \REF{ex:10:97} is taken, when the storyteller asked the rhetorical question lala ɗaw ‘[is that] good?’ the people in the audience replied lala bay ‘[it is] not good.’ (even though the answer was obvious from the story). Likewise, in \REF{ex:10:98}, the audience replied səlom ga ‘[it is] good’ to the rhetorical question səlom ga bay ɗaw ‘[is that] not good?’
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Kólo ele ango, səlom ga bay \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll k\'{ɔ}-lɔ ɛlɛ=aŋgʷɔ sʊlɔm ga baj \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls twoS+IFV-go thing=twoS.POSS good ADJ NEG {Q | \glt ‘[If] you mind your own business (lit. go to your things), [is that] not good?’
Content 4: \gsrc Kólo ele ango, səlom ga bay \textbf{ɗaw}? | \gll k\'{ɔ}-lɔ ɛlɛ=aŋgʷɔ sʊlɔm ga baj \textbf{ɗaw} | \gls twoS+IFV-go thing=twoS.POSS good ADJ NEG {Q | \glt ‘[If] you mind your own business (lit. go to your things), [is that] not good?’

Knowledge Point: A particular question tag, esəmey ‘isn’t that so’ carries an element of reproach. There is no expected answer to the question in \REF{ex:10:99}. The message is a strong declaration that the speaker had already told something to the hearer.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: These reduced interrogative pronouns are wa (from way ‘who’) in \REF{ex:10:100}, \REF{ex:10:102}, \REF{ex:10:103}, may and alma (from almay ‘what’) in \REF{ex:10:101} and \REF{ex:10:104}, respectively, malma (from malmay ‘what’) in \REF{ex:10:105}, and meme and mey (from memey ‘how’) in \REF{ex:10:106}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Wa} aməgok na \textbf{way}? | \gll \ \ \textbf{wa} amə-g=ɔk na \textbf{waj} | \gls \ \ who DEP-do=twoS.IO 3S.DO who | \glt \ \ ‘What is wrong?’ / ‘Stop crying!’ (lit. who to do it to you, who)
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Wa} andaɗay \textbf{way}? | \gll \textbf{wa} a-ndaɗ-aj \textbf{waj} | \gls who 3S-love-CL who | \glt ‘Who loves whom?' / ‘No one loves him.'
Content 4: \gsrc Kege \textbf{may} ana war ga \textbf{may}? | \gll ka-gɛ \textbf{maj} ana war ga \textbf{maj} | \gls twoS-do what DAT child ADJ what | \glt ‘What are you doing to the child, what?’ / ‘Stop doing that!’
Content 5: \gsrc \textbf{Alma} amədəvala okfom na \textbf{may}? | \gll \textbf{alma} amə-dəv=ala ɔkʷfɔm na \textbf{maj} | \gls what DEP-trip=to mouse PSP what | \glt ‘What was it that made that mouse fall? What?' / ‘What else [but a snake] makes a mouse fall?’
Content 6: \gsrc \textbf{Malma} awəlok{ }\textbf{may}? | \gll \textbf{malma} a-wəl=ɔkʷ \textbf{maj} | \gls what 3S-hurt=twoS.IO what | \glt ‘What is bothering (hurting) you? What?’ / ‘Nothing should be bothering you.’
Content 7: \gsrc \textbf{Meme} ege \textbf{mey}? | \gll \textbf{mɛmɛ} ɛ-g-ɛ \textbf{mɛj} | \gls how 3S-do-CL how? | \glt ‘What happened?’ / ‘Why did you do that?’ / ‘Stop the foolishness.’ (lit. how did it do?)

Knowledge Point: The imperative form of the verb is used for an immediate command (\ref{ex:10:107}--\ref{ex:10:109}, line 3 of \tabref{tab:83}). The verb is in the imperative mood (see \sectref{sec:7.2}) and can be preceded by a vocative. The addressee is expected to carry out the order in the immediate future as opposed to commands that demand reflection before carrying them out. In hortatory texts, imperatives are not usually found in the body of the exhortation since the hearer is expected to wait until the discourse is finished before carrying out the instructions.
Content 1: \gsrc Lohom a mogom. | \gll lɔhʷ-ɔm a mɔgʷɔm | \gls go-twoP at home | \glt ‘Go home!’
Content 2: \gsrc Cəke. | \gll tʃɪk-ɛ | \gls stand[twoS.IMP]-CL | \glt ‘Stand up!’

Knowledge Point: The word etey or ete ‘please’ can be added to other clause types (\ref{ex:10:110}--\ref{ex:10:111}, line 5 in \tabref{tab:83}) to achieve a milder pragmatic imperative force than the use of the construction without the polite adverb.
Content 1: \gsrc Nde na asaw na, gaw na \textbf{etey}? | \gll ndɛ na a-s=aw na g=aw na \textbf{ɛtɛj} | \gls so PSP 3S-please=oneS.IO PSP do=oneS.IO 3S.DO please | \glt ‘So I want that you do that for me, please.’
Content 2: \gsrc N\'{ə}njakay yam \textbf{ete} ɗaw? | \gll n\'{ə}-nzak-aj jam \textbf{ɛtɛ} ɗaw | \gls oneS+IFV-find-CL water please {Q | \glt ‘Could you please get me some water?’ (lit. can I find water please)

Knowledge Point: A negated clause in the Imperfective aspect\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Imperfective aspect|)} expresses a negative exhortation or statement of expectation (\ref{ex:10:112}--\ref{ex:10:113}, line 5 in \tabref{tab:83}). In second person \REF{ex:10:112}, the negative expectation carries a weak hortative force. The speaker is expressing that he/she expects the addressee not to carry out the action. In third person \REF{ex:10:113} the negative expectation is not hortatory, but rather simply expresses that the speaker does not expect that the action will be performed.
Content 1: \gsrc Kámənjar fabay. | \gll ká-mənz\={a}r fá-bàj | \gls twoS+IFV-see already-NEG | \glt ‘Don’t look at it yet.’ (I don’t expect you to look at it).
Content 2: \gsrc Á-mənjar fabay. | \gll á-mənz\={a}r fá-bàj | \gls 3S+IFV-see already-NEG | \glt ‘I don’t think he looked at it.’ (I don’t expect that he looked at it).
Content 3: \gsrc Kámənjar fabay. | \gll ká-mənz\={a}r fá-bàj | \gls twoS+IFV-see already-NEG | \glt ‘Don’t look at it yet.’ (I don’t expect you to look at it).
Content 4: \gsrc Á-mənjar fabay. | \gll á-mənz\={a}r fá-bàj | \gls 3S+IFV-see already-NEG | \glt ‘I don’t think he looked at it.’ (I don’t expect that he looked at it).

Knowledge Point: A clause with a verb in the Hortative mood\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Irrealis mood} (line 6 in \tabref{tab:83}, see \sectref{sec:7.4.3}) concentrates on the will of the speaker -- the speaker wishes the action done. This form is illustrated for \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s} in \REF{ex:10:114}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: An even stronger deontic form is made by the addition of an adverb of obligation (dewele ‘obligation’ \REF{ex:10:116}, səy ‘only’ \ref{ex:10:115}–\ref{ex:10:117}) preceding the clause, with the verb in Hortative mood (line 7 in \tabref{tab:83}). Imperative forms with an adverb of obligation indicate that the hearer is obligated to do something (he/she has no choice, there is no other way). These forms are used to give an order with insistence, a strong counsel.
Content 1: \gsrc Dewele səy keege na. | \gll dɛwɛlɛ sij k\`{ɛ}\`{ɛ}-gɛ na | \gls obligation only twoS+HOR-do 3S.DO | \glt ‘You are obligated to do that.’ (lit. obligation: you must only do it)
Content 2: \gsrc Səy koogom endeɓ. | \gll sij k\`{ɔ}\`{ɔ}-gʷ-ɔm ɛndɛɓ | \gls only twoP-do-twoP wisdom | \glt ‘You must be wise (lit. do only wisdom).’
Content 3: \gsrc Səy keege anga dewele. | \gll sij k\`{ɛ}\`{ɛ}-g-ɛ aŋga dɛwɛlɛ | \gls only twoS+HOR-do-CL POSS obligation | \glt ‘You must do that obligation.’ (lit. you must only do the thing that belongs to obligation)

Knowledge Point: Exclamatory sentences have either an interjection at the initial position \REF{ex:10:118} or one of several exclamatory adverbs at the final position (\ref{ex:10:119}–\ref{ex:10:122}). In the examples, the interjections and exclamatory adverbs are bolded.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kay}, nege na bay! | \gll \textbf{kaj} n\`{ɛ}-g-ɛ na baj | \gls interj. oneS+PFV-do-CL 3S.DO NEG | \glt ‘No, I didn’t do it!’
Content 2: \gsrc Apazan nok awəy Məwsa álala; | \gll apazaŋ nɔkʷ awij Muwsa á-l=ala | \gls yesterday twoS said Moses 3S+IFV-go=to | \glt ‘Yesterday you said that Moses would come;’
